results.title: A matter of survival: toxic solvents
results.creator_credit: CSIRO, S.T. Evans and J Sherman
results.brief_description:
In this 1963 film we see the dangers of working in contact with benzene vapours in a science laboratory. Most of the footage takes place in the CSIRO Chemical Research Laboratories, where the scientists enact scenes to show the safety precautions that should be observed, including avoiding breathing the vapours; avoiding spilling the liquid; replacing stoppers in bottles; washing hands; and always using the fume cupboard when pouring the liquid. The film includes an animated opening sequence, an ominous metronomic soundtrack to indicate levels of danger and footage of female scientists in the laboratory.

Produced by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO) Film Unit.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: A Matter of survival
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Canada Department of Labour, Bill Brind and Bernard Devlin
results.brief_description: Much has been said about the predicament of the blue-collar worker in the automated world of industry. This film is about a similar threat to the white-collar worker in the business world. It portrays a situation in a company where computer methods are about to be introduced to take over much of the paperwork, consequently “making surplus” a number of responsible, long-time employees. The film poses the problem from the points of view of both management and of the employees concerned. Awards: New York; Antwerp; Knokke

results.title: A Matter of survival
results.creator_credit: Tasfilm Productions, National Fitness Council of Tasmania, Don Anderson and Rodney Musch
results.brief_description: Set in the rugged Cradle Mountain region of Tasmania, this film points out the dangers of exposure for those who go into the mountains unprepared. An experienced group of walkers demonstrate, equipment, clothing, food, and techniques suitable for bushwalking.

results.title: A Matter of manners
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Colin Dean
results.brief_description: Made to improve the relations of the Commonwealth Public Service with the public, this film focuses attention on three important factors in giving service: the need for suitable office facilities in the form of counters, reception desks and entrances to government offices; The desirability of selecting counter staff and receptionists who have an aptitude for their work, expressed in the right approach to the public over the counter; the importance of systematic training for counter staff and receptionists in the fundamental and details of their jobs. Camera - Frank Bagnall. PLEASE NOTE: THIS FILM IS AVAILABLE FOR SCREENINGS TO COMMONWEALTH AND STATE GOVERNMENT DEPARTMENTS ONLY. THE PERMISSION OF THE COMMONWEALTH PUBLIC SERVICE BOARD IS NECESSARY FOR ALL OTHER SCREENINGS OF THIS TITLE.

results.title: A Matter of life and death
results.creator_credit: Archers Film Productions, Independent Producers, Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger
results.brief_description: Squadron Leader Peter Carter (David Niven), is caught between two worlds, reality, and the other which exists in his imagination that has been contaminated by war. As his plane travels over the English Channel in a ball of fire, he prepares to jump without a parachute. In what he believes are his final moments he shares his feelings on love and poetry with an American WAC, Kim Hunter. After he lands ashore he meets the WAC and they fall in love. All seems well, but a case of concussion causes Carter to experience hallucinations in which he finds himself on trial within his imaginary world. This film also features Raymond Massey, Roger Livesey and Richard Attenbourough. Also known as “Stairway to heaven”. Earthbound sequences are filmed in technicolour and Heaven sequences in black and white.

results.title: A Matter of fat
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Desmond Dew and William Weintraub
results.brief_description: A rather astonishing film showing how one man shed nearly half his body weight - 63 kg of it (140 pounds) - by complete starvation under hospital observation. What brought him to so desperate a course, and how he managed to cope with it, is told with candor and humor by the fat man himself. Lorne Greene narrates the rest. Between times, the film leaves Gilles Lorrain and his lonely struggle to examine what other overweight people are doing, singly or in groups, to reduce to more normal proportions. Medical authorities comment on some misconceptions and malpractices of the slimming industry. Narrated by Lorne Green. (Awards: Toronto; New York; Atlanta)

results.title: A Matter of dignity [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Finos Films, Anis Nohra and Michael Cacoyannis
results.brief_description: A Matter of dignity is a drama set in upper class Athens in the 1950s. It is the story of Chloe, a beautiful, young woman of high society accustomed to riches, parties, fine frocks, and an endless round of admirers. One evening Chloe discovers that her family is on the verge of bankruptcy, a situation that horrifies her snobbish, gambling, amoral mother. Chloe is pressed into falsely returning the romantic interest of a wealthy but boring suitor, who is courting her. Chloe meets and is attracted to another man, Galanos, a Greek fine art dealer who beckons her to marry him instead. A parallel tale is that of the family’s loyal maid, Katerina, who works on tirelessly for the family, despite having not been paid for months. Katerina’s five-year-old son is ill, and she desperately needs the money for his recovery. Chloe’s mother is more concerned however with keeping up appearances and throwing lavish parties for her daughter, disguising their dwindling funds. The scene is set for tragedy, the outcome of which hinges on Chloe’s choices regarding her destiny. “A Matter of dignity” is a taut study of class-consciousness, greed, the corrupting influence of money and the defining journey of one woman’s morality.

results.title: A Matter of conscience: Henry VIII and Sir Thomas More
results.creator_credit: Learning Corporation of America and Fred Zimmerman
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Western Civilization”.
An edited version of ‘A Man for All Seasons’ concentrating on the historic clash between Henry VIII and Sir Thomas More as a prototypical confrontation between the power of the state and the individual who chooses to oppose it.

results.title: A Matter of confidence: movement for children and parents (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Centre for Educational Services, Bristol Polytechnic
results.brief_description: Uses Veronica Sherbourne’s methods in a movement session for children and their parents. Shows how movement experiences presented in the form of play can develop confidence in young children. Demonstrates how relationships can develop between adult and child, and between child and child. Includes a sequence involving slow learning children. Devised and narrated by Veronica Sherbourne.

results.title: A Matter of communication (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Leonard Lee
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Focus”.
FOCUS looks at the difficulties experienced by many migrants in understanding the Anglo-Saxon legal system and investigates the way people are treated at the hands of the law. A Vietnamese man in condemned for killing a dog for consumption and a Lebanese man allegedly is bashed by police.
